verses.text: Now these are the last words of David: The oracle of David son of Jesse, the oracle of the man who was raised up on high, the anointed of the God of Jacob, the sweet psalmist of Israel:
verses.comment: Opening formula summarizing David's role; 'oracle' is modernized for 'utterance' or 'declaration'.

verses.text: The Spirit of the LORD spoke by me; his word was on my tongue.
verses.comment: Retains the direct origination of David's speech from God's Spirit.

verses.text: The God of Israel has spoken; the Rock of Israel said to me: 'He who rules over people justly, ruling in the fear of God,
verses.comment: 'People' stands for original 'men'; 'Rock' capitalized as divine title.

verses.text: is like the light of morning when the sun rises, a morning without clouds, as the shining after rain that brings grass out of the earth.'
verses.comment: Imagery maintained and clarified.

verses.text: Is not my house so with God? For he has made with me an everlasting covenant, ordered and sure. For he will make all my salvation and all my desire grow; will he not make it increase?
verses.comment: 'Make it increase' renders ambiguous Hebrew; context is provision and fulfillment.

verses.text: But worthless men are like thorns, all thrown away, for they cannot be taken with the hand.
verses.comment: 'Worthless men' translates original 'Belial'; imagery of thorns retained.

verses.text: But the one who touches them uses tools of iron or the shaft of a spear, and they are completely burned with fire on the spot.
verses.comment: Clarifies tool as 'tools of iron'; 'on the spot' renders idiom for immediacy.

verses.text: These are the names of the mighty men whom David had: Josheb-basshebeth a Tahkemonite, chief of the captains. He wielded his spear against eight hundred men whom he killed at one time.
verses.comment: 'Josheb-basshebeth' spelling modernized from variants; 'captains' for 'three.'

verses.text: After him was Eleazar son of Dodo, the Ahohite. He was among the three mighty men with David when they defied the Philistines who were gathered there for battle, and the men of Israel had withdrawn.
verses.comment: Retains sequence; 'withdrawn' for clarity instead of 'gone up.'

verses.text: He stood and struck down the Philistines until his hand grew weary and clung to the sword. And the LORD brought about a great victory that day, and the people returned after him only to take the spoil.
verses.comment: Best attempt at literal rendering; 'clung' is direct translation.

verses.text: After him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines gathered together at a field full of lentils, and the people fled from the Philistines.
verses.comment: Clarifies location: 'field full of lentils.'

verses.text: But he took his stand in the middle of the field, defended it, and struck down the Philistines. And the LORD worked a great victory.
verses.comment: Direct statement of God's agency.

verses.text: Three of the thirty chief men went down and came to David at harvest time to the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: 'At harvest time' renders Hebrew 'at the beginning of the harvest.'

verses.text: David was then in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was at Bethlehem.
verses.comment: Emphasizes fortified locations.

verses.text: David longed and said, 'Oh, that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem which is by the gate!'

So the three mighty men broke through the camp of the Philistines, drew water from the well of Bethlehem by the gate, carried it, and brought it to David. But he would not drink it; instead, he poured it out to the LORD.
verses.comment: Expanded action for clarity.

verses.text: He said, 'Far be it from me, LORD, that I should do this. Should I drink the blood of the men who risked their lives?' So he would not drink it. These things the three mighty men did.
verses.comment: 'Risked their lives' is literal for 'went at the risk of their lives.'

verses.text: Now Abishai the brother of Joab, son of Zeruiah, was chief of the Thirty. He lifted up his spear against three hundred men and killed them, and won a name among the Thirty.
He was the most honored of the Thirty and became their commander, but he did not attain to the Three.
verses.comment: 'Attain to the Three' is a Hebraism meaning not ranked with the top three.

verses.text: And Benaiah son of Jehoiada from Kabzeel, a valiant man from many deeds, struck down two sons of Ariel of Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in the middle of a pit on a snowy day.
verses.comment: 'Sons of Ariel' is uncertain in Hebrew; literal rendering, may denote Moabite champions.

verses.text: He killed an impressive Egyptian, a man with a spear in his hand. But Benaiah went down against him with a staff, snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand, and killed him with his own spear.
verses.comment: 'Impressive' follows Hebrew 'appearance'; staff/spear detail preserved.

verses.text: These are the things Benaiah son of Jehoiada did, and won a name among the thirty mighty men.
He was more honored than the Thirty, but he did not attain to the Three. And David set him over his personal guard.
verses.comment: 'Personal guard' for 'his guard' clarifies the role.

verses.text: Among the Thirty were: Asahel the brother of Joab; Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem;
Shammah the Harodite; Elika the Harodite;
verses.comment: 'Harodite' follows Hebrew. Names standardized.

verses.text: Helez the Paltite; Ira son of Ikkesh the Tekoite;
verses.comment: 'Paltite' and 'Tekoite' are places of origin.

verses.text: Abiezer the Anathothite; Mebunnai the Hushathite;
Zalmon the Ahohite; Maharai the Netophathite;
Heleb son of Baanah the Netophathite; Ittai son of Ribai from Gibeah of the Benjaminites;
Benaiah a Pirathonite; Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash;
verses.comment: 'Ravines' translates 'brooks' or 'valleys.'

verses.text: Abi-albon the Arbathite; Azmaveth the Barhumite;
Eliahba the Shaalbonite; the sons of Jashen; Jonathan;
verses.comment: Literal 'sons of Jashen'; see Chronicles variant for detail.

verses.text: Shammah the Hararite; Ahiam son of Sharar the Ararite;
verses.comment: 'Sharar' per majority Hebrew texts.

verses.text: Eliphelet son of Ahasbai, the Maacathite; Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite;
verses.comment: 'Eliam son of Ahithophel' is Bathsheba's father (see 2 Sam 11:3).

verses.text: Hezro the Carmelite; Paarai the Arbite;
Igal son of Nathan from Zobah; Bani the Gadite;
Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai the Beerothite, armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah;
Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite;
Uriah the Hittite. There were thirty-seven in all.
verses.comment: 'Thirty-seven' is a summary number inclusive of all listed, possible slight differences in other lists noted.
